ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Solid preliminary grasp of Yoruba! Went to Lagos after semester and found myself understanding far more than ever before.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Don't know if it's a strength or a weakness, but there's absolutely no hand-holding in this course: you're expected to practice everything on your own and sometimes be able to figure out patterns and new vocab on your own as well. While resourcefulness is a useful skill to know, sometimes it was a bit much, like when we're quizzed on something that we've only seen on a powerpoint slide from the week before. But if enough students complained about something he was usually willing to accommodate us so that was nice.

Strength: lots of emphasis on speaking

Weakness: assignments and due dates were quite disorganized. Made it easy to lose track of assignments and I was often unsure or unaware of which assignments I needed to do and when.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For sure if you have genuine interest in the language. If you just want an easy language, youre not going to do well or enjoy it and youll dampen the vibe of the class (so no!)
